title: OPEC+ Holds 2026 Group-wide Oil Output Steady, Agrees Capacity Mechanism
description:
Meanwhile, global SAF demand is expected to surge from 2 million metric tons in 2025 to 10 million in 2030 and 75 million by 2040, SPA reported.
Building local research infrastructure accelerates certification, supports national sustainability targets, and strengthens the country’s position in the future global aviation fuel market.
Saudi Arabia achieved a new international milestone by ranking among the top performers in the Global intellectual property perception survey 2025 (WIPO Pulse), issued by the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), which surveyed 35,500 participants from 74 countries to assess public awareness of intellectual property and its economic and social impact.
This advanced performance reflects the efforts of the Saudi Authority for Intellectual Property to enhance public awareness of and respect for intellectual property rights, as well as to expand national initiatives aimed at improving compliance and reducing violations.
These measures have helped strengthen consumer confidence in original products and underscore the societal value of intellectual property rights.
text:
King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST) has signed a new material transfer agreement (MTA) with the Arabian Petroleum Supply Company (Apsco), under which Apsco will supply KAUST with sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) for research on next-generation low-emission fuels.

According to a KAUST press release, the collaboration comes at a critical time for the aviation industry.

Under the ReFuelEU Aviation regulations, airlines are required to use a 2% SAF blend by 2025, increasing to 6% by 2030 and 70% by 2050—targets that remain out of reach with today’s fuel technologies. Meanwhile, global SAF demand is expected to surge from 2 million metric tons in 2025 to 10 million in 2030 and 75 million by 2040, SPA reported.

Professors Mani Sarathy, Thibault Guiberti, Aamir Farooq, and Hong Im will lead the research, which will focus on the chemical properties, reaction pathways, and combustion behavior of the provided fuels. The new data on fuel behavior, emissions characteristics, and performance metrics will build a comprehensive database that will develop models for the creation of future SAF formulations of higher efficiency and lower environmental impact.

“This partnership allows us to combine world-class experimental facilities with advanced artificial intelligence to fundamentally reimagine how sustainable aviation fuels are designed,” said Sarathy. “Using the new data generated, our models will help identify efficient, cleaner, and more scalable fuel formulations that can support the aviation sector’s ambitious climate goals.”

The release also highlighted that globally, the aviation industry is increasingly turning to create predictive models for fuel behavior from partial datasets, reducing development cycles from years to months. Beyond fuel design, the project will help bridge critical knowledge gaps that currently slow SAF adoption worldwide, from understanding emissions behavior to assessing how fuels perform across a range of operating environments. By answering these fundamental questions, the partnership will enable industry and regulators to make faster, more informed decisions about future SAF deployment.

Apsco CEO Dr. Azzam Qari stated, “This collaboration with KAUST marks an important milestone for Apsco and for the future of sustainable aviation in the Kingdom. As the global aviation sector moves rapidly toward lower-carbon solutions, investing in local research and national capabilities in SAF is no longer optional; it is strategic. Through this agreement, our role goes beyond supplying fuel for testing; we are helping build the scientific and technical foundation that can enable Saudi-developed SAF technologies in the years ahead.”

Moreover, as Saudi Arabia expands its aviation network and explores domestic SAF production opportunities, the ability to test and validate fuel properties within the Kingdom scientifically becomes increasingly essential. Building local research infrastructure accelerates certification, supports national sustainability targets, and strengthens the country’s position in the future global aviation fuel market. With research facilities already in place, KAUST will provide the scientific foundation needed to accelerate domestic SAF research in the Kingdom, supporting the goals of the Saudi Aviation Strategy to advance low-carbon, next generation energy technologies.

Saudi Arabia achieved a new international milestone by ranking among the top performers in the Global intellectual property perception survey 2025 (WIPO Pulse), issued by the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), which surveyed 35,500 participants from 74 countries to assess public awareness of intellectual property and its economic and social impact.

The Kingdom ranked among the highest globally in awareness of the role of intellectual property in supporting the economy, with national awareness of its impact on economic growth and innovation reaching approximately 80%, placing it at the top of this global indicator, according to SPA.

Saudi Arabia also recorded notable growth in youth and women’s awareness of intellectual property rights, making it a leading contributor to raising the average performance of countries in the Asia-Pacific region in this area.

This advanced performance reflects the efforts of the Saudi Authority for Intellectual Property to enhance public awareness of and respect for intellectual property rights, as well as to expand national initiatives aimed at improving compliance and reducing violations.

These measures have helped strengthen consumer confidence in original products and underscore the societal value of intellectual property rights.

British finance minister Rachel Reeves on Sunday denied she misled the public over official forecasts ahead of this month's budget, saying she had been honest about the need to build up a bigger fiscal buffer.

In a speech on November 4, Reeves appeared to lay the groundwork to break the Labour Party's promise to voters before the 2024 election and raise income tax rates, citing a "weaker than previously thought" productivity performance.

In a letter published on Friday, the head of Britain's budget watchdog said it had also provided the government with forecasts showing that its productivity downgrade was offset by increases in real wages and inflation - which Reeves did not mention.

The letter added to questions about the government's communications ahead of Wednesday's budget. November saw big swings in the British government bond market as investors grappled with shifts in tone from the government over the prospect of tax increases.

Its publication prompted the opposition Conservative Party to demand that Reeves resign for misleading the public about the economic situation ahead of her November 26 budget.

According to Reuters, Reeves told the BBC that she intended to stay as finance minister for a long time.

"I have been underestimated all the way through my life," Reeves said. "I'm proud of my budget this week."

The confidential forecasts provided to Reeves by the Office for Budget Responsibility watchdog before her November 4 speech showed she would meet her fiscal rules by a margin of 4.2 billion pounds, not including any budget measures or the reversal of welfare cuts earlier in the year.

On Sunday, Reeves told Sky News that boosting that buffer - which would have been very thin by historical standards - was her main concern, which required her to deliver a tough message to the public.

"The just over 4 billion pounds surplus was not enough," Reeves said. "The headroom would not have been enough, and it would not give the Bank of England space to continue cutting interest rates."

When the budget was announced on Wednesday, Reeves had more than doubled her headroom against the fiscal rules to 21.7 billion pounds from 9.9 billion pounds in her previous fiscal plan.

title: African finance ministers push for bankable projects, private capital at AfDB Investment Forum - IOL
description:
Image: Supplied African finance ministers attending the 2025 Africa Investment Forum (AIF) have called for a decisive shift from highlighting potential opportunities to delivering execution-ready, investment-grade projects.
Côte d’Ivoire’s Minister of Economic Planning and Development, Nialé Kaba, said Africa’s biggest obstacle remains project readiness.
She highlighted Côte d’Ivoire’s progress, including simplified investment codes and single-window systems that have helped lift private investment from 12% of GDP in 2020 to 20% today.
Nabe described the Africa Investment Forum as a “compass” for guiding co-financing and innovation.
Ethiopian Finance Minister Ahmed Shide detailed sweeping reforms underway in Ethiopia, including foreign exchange liberalisation, customs reforms and the creation of a securities exchange.
text:
Speaking during the Ministerial Dialogue on Accelerating Private Investment Through Conducive Enabling Environments, ministers from Côte d’Ivoire, Ethiopia, Guinea, Mauritania, Morocco and Zambia outlined the reforms required to strengthen investor confidence, improve regulatory frameworks and build resilient business environments capable of attracting long-term funding.

Image: Supplied

African finance ministers attending the 2025 Africa Investment Forum (AIF) have called for a decisive shift from highlighting potential opportunities to delivering execution-ready, investment-grade projects.

Their message was clear: the continent’s transformation must be driven by private capital, not aid.

Speaking during the Ministerial Dialogue on Accelerating Private Investment Through Conducive Enabling Environments, ministers from Côte d’Ivoire, Ethiopia, Guinea, Mauritania, Morocco and Zambia outlined the reforms required to strengthen investor confidence, improve regulatory frameworks and build resilient business environments capable of attracting long-term funding.

Côte d’Ivoire’s Minister of Economic Planning and Development, Nialé Kaba, said Africa’s biggest obstacle remains project readiness.

“Africa’s problem is that opportunities and projects are not mature,” she said. She highlighted Côte d’Ivoire’s progress, including simplified investment codes and single-window systems that have helped lift private investment from 12% of GDP in 2020 to 20% today.

Zambia’s Minister of Finance and National Planning Situmbeko Musokotwane said the country is emerging from its debt crisis, supported by an improved credit rating.

Over the past three years, Zambia has secured nearly $2 billion in public-private partnerships and attracted more than $7 billion in new mining investment. He noted that streamlining project approvals to under 45 days has helped unlock billions in private energy investments.

Musokotwane also spotlighted the privately financed Lobito Corridor, set to become Africa’s first east-west transcontinental rail link, which will connect Zambia and the DRC to Angola’s Atlantic ports.

Morocco’s Economy and Finance Minister Nadia Fettah stressed that investors are no longer looking for potential, but for “ready projects delivered with speed and strong execution capacity.”

She urged African governments to maintain a year-round pipeline of regional projects and argued that pooling resources across borders is essential for large-scale developments in rail, aviation and data infrastructure.

Mauritania’s Minister of Economic Affairs and Development, Abdullah Suleiman Sheikh Sidiya, said Africa is increasingly seen as an investment destination rather than an aid-dependent continent.

“Africa is becoming a sought-after destination—not only for cooperation but increasingly for investment,” he said.

Guinea’s Minister of Planning and International Cooperation, Ismael Nabe, underscored the role of strong project preparation in lowering investment risk. He highlighted Guinea’s UK-Export Finance-backed Administrative City as a model of replicable development, inspired by similar projects in Benin.

Nabe described the Africa Investment Forum as a “compass” for guiding co-financing and innovation. Successful initiatives in one country, he said, can be adapted across the region through blended finance tools and partnerships with institutions such as the African Development Bank Group and Middle Eastern sovereign funds.

Ethiopian Finance Minister Ahmed Shide detailed sweeping reforms underway in Ethiopia, including foreign exchange liberalisation, customs reforms and the creation of a securities exchange.

title: Yohannes Abera's Post - LinkedIn
description:
Proud to announce the successful handover of Ethiopia’s Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) Feasibility Study.
In line with the commitment made at the 41st ICAO Assembly to support developing countries toward achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, Ethiopia has been advancing its SAF agenda over the past two years.
Supported by the EU under ICAO’s ACT-SAF program, a comprehensive feasibility study has now been finalized.
SAF development aligns perfectly with our national commitment to sustainability and climate-resilient growth.
The study confirms that Ethiopia, endowed with rich natural resources, holds strong potential to produce Sustainable Aviation Fuel domestically—reducing aviation emissions by up to 80% compared to conventional fuel.
text: Proud to announce the successful handover of Ethiopia’s Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) Feasibility Study. In line with the commitment made at the 41st ICAO Assembly to support developing countries toward achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, Ethiopia has been advancing its SAF agenda over the past two years. Supported by the EU under ICAO’s ACT-SAF program, a comprehensive feasibility study has now been finalized. On November 27, 2025, the study was officially handed over by ICAO’s ACT-SAF Project Coordinator, Mr. Cesar Velarde, to Ethiopia’s Minister of Transport and Logistics, H.E. Dr. Alemu Sime, in Addis Ababa. During the ceremony, we highlighted Ethiopia’s exceptional Green Legacy initiative, with over 46 billion trees planted in the past six years—one of the world’s most impactful environmental efforts. SAF development aligns perfectly with our national commitment to sustainability and climate-resilient growth. The study confirms that Ethiopia, endowed with rich natural resources, holds strong potential to produce Sustainable Aviation Fuel domestically—reducing aviation emissions by up to 80% compared to conventional fuel. With continued collaboration. My sincere appreciation to all stakeholders, experts, and government institutions who contributed to this milestone. Together, we are shaping a greener future for Ethiopian aviation.

title: Singapura vai adotar taxa climática nas passagens aéreas - Pontos pra Voar
description:
Singapura vai adotar uma taxa climática nas passagens aéreas, com o objetivo de fomentar o uso de Combustível Sustenção de Aviação (SAF – Sustainable Aviation Fuel) e dar novo impulso à descarbonização da aviação.
Segundo o anúncio da Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS), as passagens vendidas a partir de 1º de abril de 2026, para voos que partem de Singapura a partir de 1º de outubro de 2026, já terão incorporada a taxa.
Em paralelo, a meta da CAAS prevê que o uso obrigatório de SAF nos voos de partida de Singapura seja implementado já em 2026.
O custo da nova taxa climática para os viajantes partindo de Singapura será modesto – mas simbólico.
Com a nova taxa climática sobre passagens, Singapura buscar atuar junto à aviação de maneira mais verde.
text:
Singapura vai adotar uma taxa climática nas passagens aéreas, com o objetivo de fomentar o uso de Combustível Sustenção de Aviação (SAF – Sustainable Aviation Fuel) e dar novo impulso à descarbonização da aviação.

Segundo o anúncio da Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS), as passagens vendidas a partir de 1º de abril de 2026, para voos que partem de Singapura a partir de 1º de outubro de 2026, já terão incorporada a taxa.

Detalhes da medida

A taxa varia conforme destino e classe da viagem. Por exemplo, para voos dentro do Sudeste Asiático, cobrança de SGD 1 (≈ US$ 0,77) em classe econômica; para rotas longas (como às Américas) pode atingir SGD 10,40 ou mais para econômica, e valores maiores para as classes premium.

O valor arrecadado será destinado à compra centralizada de SAF, produzido a partir de óleos residuais ou biomassa, garantindo uma mistura mínima de 1% de SAF a partir de 2026, e avançando para entre 3% e 5% até 2030, conforme disponibilidade e preço do mercado.

Em paralelo, a meta da CAAS prevê que o uso obrigatório de SAF nos voos de partida de Singapura seja implementado já em 2026.

O custo da nova taxa climática para os viajantes partindo de Singapura será modesto – mas simbólico. Ela cria um mecanismo de compartilhamento de despesas entre setor aéreo, passageiros e combustíveis sustentáveis.

Embora a aviação responda por cerca de 1,2% das emissões globais de gases de efeito estufa, seu desafio de descarbonização é elevado: o SAF segue com produção limitada (em torno de 0,3% do combustível em 2023) e custo maior que o querosene fóssil tradicional.

Eventuais desafios e observações

A produção de SAF ainda está restrita: garantir mix mínimo e escala será um gargalo para que a meta de 1% em 2026 seja factível.

A comunicação ao passageiro precisa ser transparente para evitar percepções de “taxa surpresa”.

O impacto competitivo da medida será limitado em termos de preço ao consumidor, mas pode crescer se o mix de SAF precisar ser ampliado significativamente.

Com a nova taxa climática sobre passagens, Singapura buscar atuar junto à aviação de maneira mais verde. A introdução da cobrança a partir de 2026 e a obrigatoriedade do SAF representam um modelo inovador para o setor aéreo. Acompanhar como será implementada e se outras regiões seguirão será crucial para o futuro da aviação sustentável.

Para Saber Mais

Para ler outras notícias que publicamos recentemente no Pontos pra Voar, clique aqui.

Que tal nos acompanhar no Instagram para não perder nossas lives e também nos seguir em nosso canal no Telegram?

O Pontos pra Voar pode eventualmente receber comissões em compras realizadas através de alguns dos links e banners dispostos em nosso site, sem que isso tenha qualquer impacto no preço final do produto ou serviço por você adquirido.

Quando publicamos artigos patrocinados, estes são claramente identificados ao longo do texto. Para mais informações, consulte nossa Política de Privacidade.

Não usamos inteligência artificial na geração de conteúdo do Pontos pra Voar. Os conteúdos são autorais e produzidos pelos nossos editores.

title: Ministry Of Culture And Emirates Association Sign Cooperation Agreement - OneArabia
description:
Local -OneArabia The Ministry of Culture and the Emirates Association for Social Development in Ras Al Khaimah have entered into a cooperation agreement.
It also seeks to expand cultural and social awareness programmes, empower youth, and strengthen the national identity.
They plan to conduct events and training workshops focusing on national identity, heritage, and culture.
He emphasised that cultural development is a shared responsibility that helps raise awareness and positively shape individuals.
Dr. Mohammed Abdul Latif Khalifa highlighted the significance of institutional cooperation in achieving sustainable cultural and social development.
text:
Local

-OneArabia

The Ministry of Culture and the Emirates Association for Social Development in Ras Al Khaimah have entered into a cooperation agreement. This partnership aims to enhance national collaborations and support cultural growth. It also seeks to expand cultural and social awareness programmes, empower youth, and strengthen the national identity. The agreement was signed by Mubarak Al Nakhi and Dr. Mohammed Abdul Latif Khalifa, with key officials present.

Under this agreement, both organisations will collaborate on cultural and community initiatives. They plan to conduct events and training workshops focusing on national identity, heritage, and culture. Additionally, they will work together on research projects, share expertise, and support various community initiatives to increase cultural awareness across different societal groups.

Mubarak Al Nakhi expressed that this partnership underscores the Ministry's dedication to building effective relationships with community institutions. He stated, "This agreement reflects the Ministry’s commitment to nurturing effective partnerships with community institutions, which is crucial to strengthening the national cultural landscape." He emphasised that cultural development is a shared responsibility that helps raise awareness and positively shape individuals.

The agreement places emphasis on nurturing Emirati talents by advancing national cultural and artistic programmes. It aims to empower community associations by providing access to specialised cultural content. Furthermore, it encourages collaboration in documentation, publishing, and organising joint cultural events.

Dr. Mohammed Abdul Latif Khalifa highlighted the significance of institutional cooperation in achieving sustainable cultural and social development. He remarked that the Association values this partnership greatly as it paves the way for innovative community initiatives.

Commitment to National Identity

This collaboration reflects the Ministry of Culture's ongoing efforts to create an inclusive cultural ecosystem. It aims to strengthen ties with civil society institutions while reinforcing culture's role in empowering individuals. The agreement also seeks to consolidate values such as social belongingness, loyalty, and national identity.

Mubarak Al Nakhi added that this partnership enables them to expand cultural engagement further. He said it allows for launching programmes that bolster national identity and support community involvement while introducing new ventures aligned with 'We the UAE 2031' Vision objectives.

Dr. Mohammed Abdul Latif Khalifa noted that this agreement highlights the importance of institutional cooperation in achieving sustainable development goals. His Excellency mentioned that it will pave the way for pioneering community initiatives.

With inputs from WAM

Story first published: Sunday, November 30, 2025, 19:07 [GST]

title: A Game Theoretic Approach in Modelling the Competition of Aviation Fuel Production Firms ...
authors: Jeremy Gabriel Uy, Jayne Lois San Juan
description:
Abstract Amongst all efforts to decarbonize the aviation industry, sustainable aviation fuel has proven to be the most popular technologically matured innovation that could pose a significant impact on mitigating climate change.
While optimization studies that aid stakeholders in making decisions regarding production and using sustainable aviation fuel has been on the rise, the current pool of literature does not look into the competitive dynamics of the aviation fuel production firms.
A simultaneous game theoretic mathematical optimization model is developed to understand the Cournot dynamics of the competition of conventional and sustainable aviation fuel production firms.
This model aids production firms in making decisions based on anticipated market behaviour considering its highly competitive nature.
Results demonstrate strategies by both conventional and sustainable aviation fuel production firms that satisfies the equilibrium of both parties, each having a profit of USD 13,730.11.
text:
Abstract

Amongst all efforts to decarbonize the aviation industry, sustainable aviation fuel has proven to be the most popular technologically matured innovation that could pose a significant impact on mitigating climate change. While optimization studies that aid stakeholders in making decisions regarding production and using sustainable aviation fuel has been on the rise, the current pool of literature does not look into the competitive dynamics of the aviation fuel production firms. A simultaneous game theoretic mathematical optimization model is developed to understand the Cournot dynamics of the competition of conventional and sustainable aviation fuel production firms. A Fuzzy Cournot Optimization Approach is used to solve the model. This model aids production firms in making decisions based on anticipated market behaviour considering its highly competitive nature. An illustrative case study is carried out to understand the behaviour of the optimization model. Scenario analysis including varying the prices and considering book-and-claim strategy are also done. Results demonstrate strategies by both conventional and sustainable aviation fuel production firms that satisfies the equilibrium of both parties, each having a profit of USD 13,730.11.

title: Techno-economic Analysis of Sustainable Aviation Fuel Production from Corn Stover in the ...
authors: John Frederick D. Tapia, Alexandra Mirfi Abrasia, Jahsiel Ann Dalisay, Julia Aliana Halili, Alexandra Francesca Miguel, Kylie Marie Mangali, Christine Joselle Lopez, Dominic C. Y. Foo, Raymond R. Tan
description:
Abstract The growing demand for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) has driven innovation in alternative fuel technologies, with synthetic paraffinic kerosene (SPK) emerging as a viable candidate as it offers a reduction in environmental footprint compared to conventional fossil fuels.
In this study, the feasibility of biomass-derived SPK was explored, utilizing corn stover as the process feedstock.
The designed process integrates key thermochemical processes such as gasification, Fischer-Tropsch (FT) synthesis, and hydrocracking, to convert corn stover into SPK.
The remaining CO2 in the FT fuel underwent flashing and adsorption, enabling 63.27 % recovery for reuse in steam and power plants.
The product selling prices were also ascertained alongside a breakeven analysis to ensure that the manufacturing operation remains economically viable.
text:
Abstract

The growing demand for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) has driven innovation in alternative fuel technologies, with synthetic paraffinic kerosene (SPK) emerging as a viable candidate as it offers a reduction in environmental footprint compared to conventional fossil fuels. In this study, the feasibility of biomass-derived SPK was explored, utilizing corn stover as the process feedstock. The designed process integrates key thermochemical processes such as gasification, Fischer-Tropsch (FT) synthesis, and hydrocracking, to convert corn stover into SPK. The process was simulated in commercial software Aspen Plus V12, where its material and energy flows were analyzed. Moreover, the Anderson-Schulz Flory distribution model was used to determine the FT product distribution. The simulation results show a 75 % molar conversion of carbon monoxide and a biomass-to-SPK conversion of 6 % was achieved. The sustainability of the developed process was assessed through its carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, with syngas cleaning reducing emissions by 30.70 %, resulting in a carbon footprint of 0.58 kg CO2/kg syngas. The remaining CO2 in the FT fuel underwent flashing and adsorption, enabling 63.27 % recovery for reuse in steam and power plants. Subsequently, the total capital investment, including working and fixed capitals, were estimated. The FT-SPK pathway was proven to be costly due to the energy-intensive processes. However, a positive ROI and a payback period within 5 y were achieved. The product selling prices were also ascertained alongside a breakeven analysis to ensure that the manufacturing operation remains economically viable.

OPEC+ countries agreed to maintain group-wide oil output quotas for 2026 in a meeting on Sunday, and also agreed on a mechanism to assess members' maximum oil production capacity, OPEC said in a statement.
OPEC+ groups the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and allies led by Russia.
OPEC+ has paused oil output hikes for the first quarter of 2026 after releasing some 2.9 million barrels per day into the market since April 2025.
This advanced performance reflects the efforts of the Saudi Authority for Intellectual Property to enhance public awareness of and respect for intellectual property rights, as well as to expand national initiatives aimed at improving compliance and reducing violations.
These measures have helped strengthen consumer confidence in original products and underscore the societal value of intellectual property rights.
text:
OPEC+ countries agreed to maintain group-wide oil output quotas for 2026 in a meeting on Sunday, and also agreed on a mechanism to assess members' maximum oil production capacity, OPEC said in a statement.

Eight OPEC+ countries, holding a separate meeting on Sunday, also have an agreement in principle to maintain a pause in their output hikes for the first quarter of 2026, an OPEC+ source and a person familiar with OPEC+ talks said earlier, according to Reuters.

The meeting of OPEC+, which pumps half of the world's oil, comes during a fresh US effort to broker a Russia-Ukraine peace deal, which could add to oil supply if sanctions on Russia are eased. Ministers have started a series of online meetings, two sources said.

If the peace deal fails, Russia could see its supply curbed further by sanctions. OPEC+ groups the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and allies led by Russia.

OVER 3 MLN BPD OF OUTPUT CUTS STILL IN PLACE

Brent crude closed on Friday near $63 a barrel, down 15% this year.

OPEC+ has paused oil output hikes for the first quarter of 2026 after releasing some 2.9 million barrels per day into the market since April 2025.

The group still has about 3.24 million bpd of output cuts in place, representing around 3% of global demand, and the Sunday meeting did not alter those.

OPEC said the group had approved a mechanism to assess members' maximum production capacity to be used for setting output quotas from 2027.

Saudi Arabia achieved a new international milestone by ranking among the top performers in the Global intellectual property perception survey 2025 (WIPO Pulse), issued by the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), which surveyed 35,500 participants from 74 countries to assess public awareness of intellectual property and its economic and social impact.

The Kingdom ranked among the highest globally in awareness of the role of intellectual property in supporting the economy, with national awareness of its impact on economic growth and innovation reaching approximately 80%, placing it at the top of this global indicator, according to SPA.

Saudi Arabia also recorded notable growth in youth and women’s awareness of intellectual property rights, making it a leading contributor to raising the average performance of countries in the Asia-Pacific region in this area.

This advanced performance reflects the efforts of the Saudi Authority for Intellectual Property to enhance public awareness of and respect for intellectual property rights, as well as to expand national initiatives aimed at improving compliance and reducing violations.

These measures have helped strengthen consumer confidence in original products and underscore the societal value of intellectual property rights.

In a speech on November 4, Reeves appeared to lay the groundwork to break the Labour Party's promise to voters before the 2024 election and raise income tax rates, citing a "weaker than previously thought" productivity performance.

In a letter published on Friday, the head of Britain's budget watchdog said it had also provided the government with forecasts showing that its productivity downgrade was offset by increases in real wages and inflation - which Reeves did not mention.

The letter added to questions about the government's communications ahead of Wednesday's budget. November saw big swings in the British government bond market as investors grappled with shifts in tone from the government over the prospect of tax increases.

Its publication prompted the opposition Conservative Party to demand that Reeves resign for misleading the public about the economic situation ahead of her November 26 budget.

According to Reuters, Reeves told the BBC that she intended to stay as finance minister for a long time.

"I have been underestimated all the way through my life," Reeves said. "I'm proud of my budget this week."

The confidential forecasts provided to Reeves by the Office for Budget Responsibility watchdog before her November 4 speech showed she would meet her fiscal rules by a margin of 4.2 billion pounds, not including any budget measures or the reversal of welfare cuts earlier in the year.

On Sunday, Reeves told Sky News that boosting that buffer - which would have been very thin by historical standards - was her main concern, which required her to deliver a tough message to the public.

"The just over 4 billion pounds surplus was not enough," Reeves said. "The headroom would not have been enough, and it would not give the Bank of England space to continue cutting interest rates."

When the budget was announced on Wednesday, Reeves had more than doubled her headroom against the fiscal rules to 21.7 billion pounds from 9.9 billion pounds in her previous fiscal plan.

title: Reclaiming The Land: Choosing Farming Over Exodus - The Reporter Ethiopia
description:
Among the beneficiaries is Alemu’s father, 50-year-old Baba Morki, a lifelong farmer in AbjataKebele of Adami Tulu JidoKombolchaWoreda.
For the first time, he no longer relies on grid electricity, and year-round farming has become possible.
Young people, once determined to flee the village, are beginning to see farming as a viable livelihood rather than a last resort.
He had saved what little he could from long shifts, fully prepared to attempt the clandestine route through Djibouti.
“Now I see young people making something of themselves here, if they can get land.
text:
In a quiet village just outside the bustling town of Batu—where Dutch-owned flower farms dominate the landscape—23-year-old Alemu Baba has chosen a path that many of his peers have long abandoned: he has become a farmer.

While most young men from his community embark on perilous journeys toward Yemen and Libya, gambling their lives for a chance to reach Europe or the Gulf, Alemu returned home. After months working as a construction laborer in Bishoftu for a wage he says “barely covered daily expenses,” he faced a future that, in his words, “looked completely empty.”

“I didn’t see a way forward in the city, and people my age thought farming had no future,” he said. “But now I’m earning enough to support my family, and I’m even planning to expand into bee farming.”

Alemu is part of a growing cohort of young people finding new promise in agriculture, aided by the Global Green Growth Institute (GGGI), a Seoul-based organization working to modernize farming in low-income communities. Over the past two years, the Institute has introduced training and technology to roughly 400 farmers in the region, helping them shift from subsistence production to sustainable, market-oriented agriculture. The effort—funded by the Italian government under a project titled Fostering Food Security to Prevent Conflict and Ensure Stability—includes access to vermicompost, climate-smart tools, and support to help farmers become food secure and profitable.

Among the beneficiaries is Alemu’s father, 50-year-old Baba Morki, a lifelong farmer in AbjataKebele of Adami Tulu JidoKombolchaWoreda. He has witnessed not only his own transformation but that of his neighbors.

Baba has been part of the program from the start, receiving training in entrepreneurship, organic market linkages, and the use of solar-powered irrigation systems—three of which now irrigate a combined 130 hectares in an area once defined by chronic water shortages. For the first time, he no longer relies on grid electricity, and year-round farming has become possible.

“In the past, if the weather failed us, we sold livestock just to survive,” he said. “It kept us poor and without hope.”

Today, Baba says, the change is visible everywhere. Herds are growing. Income is more stable. Young people, once determined to flee the village, are beginning to see farming as a viable livelihood rather than a last resort.

“Before, our work was seasonal and labor intensive. Now we farm continuously, earn more, and finally dream bigger for our children,” he said. “They no longer need to leave home to build a future.”

Both Baba and his son have earned enough from their fields to build modern homes—an unlikely outcome just a few years ago.

GGGI, which began operations in Ethiopia in 2010, aims to help the country build a climate-resilient green economy by 2030 and reduce its reliance on emergency food aid. More than 10 million Ethiopians currently require humanitarian assistance, according to the United Nations.

The shift toward sustainable agriculture is also reshaping young people’s aspirations beyond the farms themselves. In Batu, 21-year-old waiter and tourism graduate Brook Teshome recalls planning his own journey abroad. He had saved what little he could from long shifts, fully prepared to attempt the clandestine route through Djibouti.

But watching farmers—including his older brother—reap the benefits of the new practices has changed his thinking.

“I used to believe the only way to succeed was to leave,” he said. “Now I see young people making something of themselves here, if they can get land. I’m even considering becoming a farmer instead of working for someone else.”

A similar transformation is underway in Bulbula, where farmer AmanGemeda has expanded his operations with the help of solar irrigation and vermicompost on land that now sits alongside the new Batu–Hawassa freeway.

Aman says that many people are seeing farming in a different light.“My experience is showing others that farming can be different—that we’re not defined by the shortages and hunger that once shaped our lives,” Aman said.

title: KAUST And Apsco Collaborate To Enhance Sustainable Aviation Fuel Research
description:
This partnership will see Apsco supply sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) to KAUST for research on advanced low-emission fuels.
"This partnership allows us to combine world-class experimental facilities with advanced artificial intelligence to fundamentally reimagine how sustainable aviation fuels are designed," said Sarathy.
Developing local research infrastructure accelerates certification processes, supports national sustainability goals, and strengthens Saudi Arabia's position in the future global aviation fuel market.
KAUST's existing research facilities provide a solid foundation for advancing domestic SAF research in line with the Saudi Aviation Strategy's objectives of promoting low-carbon energy technologies.
This initiative is crucial as Saudi Arabia aims to enhance its role in sustainable aviation fuel development globally.
text:
Local

-OneArabia

King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST) has entered into a material transfer agreement with the Arabian Petroleum Supply Company (Apsco). This partnership will see Apsco supply sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) to KAUST for research on advanced low-emission fuels. The collaboration is timely, as the aviation industry faces increasing pressure to adopt cleaner fuel technologies.

Under the ReFuelEU Aviation regulations, airlines must use a 2% SAF blend by 2025, which will rise to 6% by 2030 and 70% by 2050. Current fuel technologies are insufficient to meet these targets. Global demand for SAF is projected to grow significantly, from 2 million metric tons in 2025 to 10 million in 2030 and reaching 75 million by 2040.

The research at KAUST will be led by Professors Mani Sarathy, Thibault Guiberti, Aamir Farooq, and Hong Im. Their work will concentrate on understanding the chemical properties, reaction pathways, and combustion behavior of the supplied fuels. This research aims to develop a comprehensive database that will aid in creating future SAF formulations with higher efficiency and lower environmental impact.

"This partnership allows us to combine world-class experimental facilities with advanced artificial intelligence to fundamentally reimagine how sustainable aviation fuels are designed," said Sarathy. "Using the new data generated, our models will help identify efficient, cleaner, and more scalable fuel formulations that can support the aviation sector’s ambitious climate goals."

The aviation industry worldwide is increasingly using predictive models for fuel behavior based on partial datasets. This approach reduces development cycles from years to months. The project aims not only at designing better fuels but also at addressing knowledge gaps that hinder SAF adoption globally. By understanding emissions behavior and assessing performance across various environments, the partnership seeks to enable faster decision-making regarding SAF deployment.

Apsco CEO Dr. Azzam Qari remarked, "This collaboration with KAUST marks an important milestone for Apsco and for the future of sustainable aviation in the Kingdom. As the global aviation sector moves rapidly toward lower-carbon solutions, investing in local research and national capabilities in SAF is no longer optional; it is strategic."

Strategic Importance for Saudi Arabia

Saudi Arabia's expanding aviation network and exploration of domestic SAF production opportunities make scientific testing of fuel properties within the Kingdom increasingly vital. Developing local research infrastructure accelerates certification processes, supports national sustainability goals, and strengthens Saudi Arabia's position in the future global aviation fuel market.

KAUST's existing research facilities provide a solid foundation for advancing domestic SAF research in line with the Saudi Aviation Strategy's objectives of promoting low-carbon energy technologies. This initiative is crucial as Saudi Arabia aims to enhance its role in sustainable aviation fuel development globally.

With inputs from SPA

title: GASTAT Launches Road To Riyadh Program For 2026 UN World Data Forum - OneArabia
description:
This initiative is part of the preparations for hosting the sixth United Nations World Data Forum in Riyadh from November 9 to 12, 2026.
The program's first activities began alongside the Second Statistical Forum for Universities and Statistical Associations in Jeddah, coinciding with World Statistics Day.
The "Road to Riyadh" program aims to boost global recognition of Saudi Arabia's leadership in data and statistics.
The sixth UN World Data Forum will follow from November 9 to 12, 2026.
The "Road to Riyadh" program is part of GASTAT's ongoing efforts to enhance Saudi Arabia's standing in the statistical field.
text:
Local

-OneArabia

The General Authority for Statistics (GASTAT) has initiated the "Road to Riyadh" program. This initiative is part of the preparations for hosting the sixth United Nations World Data Forum in Riyadh from November 9 to 12, 2026. The program's first activities began alongside the Second Statistical Forum for Universities and Statistical Associations in Jeddah, coinciding with World Statistics Day.

The "Road to Riyadh" program aims to boost global recognition of Saudi Arabia's leadership in data and statistics. It highlights the Kingdom's efforts in digital transformation and developing a robust statistical ecosystem. These initiatives support achieving the Sustainable Development Goals and align with Saudi Vision 2030, which seeks a knowledge-based economy driven by statistical data.

The program fosters collaboration with experts, institutions, and statistical agencies worldwide. This collaboration facilitates knowledge exchange and strengthens international partnerships in data and statistical indicators. The activities include both in-person and virtual sessions, seminars, and workshops across various cities in Saudi Arabia.

These events will continue throughout the year until the Second Saudi Forum for Statistics on November 8. The sixth UN World Data Forum will follow from November 9 to 12, 2026. GASTAT has made the full program accessible on its official website for those interested in participating or learning more about these initiatives.

The "Road to Riyadh" program is part of GASTAT's ongoing efforts to enhance Saudi Arabia's standing in the statistical field. It builds on achievements that have contributed to the Kingdom's progress in various international indicators. These efforts demonstrate Saudi Arabia's commitment to leading advancements in data and statistics globally.

By hosting such significant events, Saudi Arabia aims to showcase its role as a pioneer in data-driven development. The focus is on creating a sustainable future through informed decision-making supported by comprehensive statistical analysis.

With inputs from SPA

title: Global airlines race to fix Airbus jets; US reports little disruption - The Standard (HK)
description:
Global airlines scrambled to fix a software glitch on Airbus A320 jets on Saturday as a partial recall by the European planemaker halted hundreds of flights in Asia and Europe and threatened U.S. travel over the busiest weekend of the year.
Airlines worked through the night after global regulators told them to remedy the problem before resuming flights.
Airlines that said they had completed or nearly finished all their software updates on Saturday included American Airlines, United Airlines, Air India, Delta Air Lines, Hungary’s Wizz Air, Mexico's Volaris, Air Arabia, Saudi Arabia's Flyadeal, and Taiwan's carriers.
AIRBUS RECALL LUCKY TIMING FOR SOME AIRLINES The alert landed at a time of day when many European airlines and Asian airlines are winding down their schedules, leaving time for repairs.
About 140 jets in the company's fleet of A320, A321 and A220 aircraft did not need the fix, the company said.
text:
Global airlines scrambled to fix a software glitch on Airbus A320 jets on Saturday as a partial recall by the European planemaker halted hundreds of flights in Asia and Europe and threatened U.S. travel over the busiest weekend of the year.

Airlines worked through the night after global regulators told them to remedy the problem before resuming flights.

Airlines that said they had completed or nearly finished all their software updates on Saturday included American Airlines, United Airlines, Air India, Delta Air Lines, Hungary’s Wizz Air, Mexico's Volaris, Air Arabia, Saudi Arabia's Flyadeal, and Taiwan's carriers. Many reported no impact on operations.

The overnight effort by airlines appeared to help head off the worst-case scenario and capped the number of flight delays in Asia and Europe. In the United States, which will face high demand after the Thanksgiving holiday period, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said that impacted U.S. carriers "have reported great progress, and are on track to meet the deadline of this Sunday at midnight to complete the work."

He posted on X that travellers "SHOULD NOT expect any major disruptions," although one U.S. airline, JetBlue, later said it cancelled dozens of flights that had been scheduled for Sunday.

Asia-based aviation analyst Brendan Sobie said the update was "not as chaotic as some people might think," although "it does create some short-term headaches for operations."

Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury apologised to airlines and passengers after the surprise recall of 6,000 planes, or more than half of the global A320-family fleet, which recently overtook the Boeing 737 as the industry's most-delivered model.

"I want to sincerely apologise to our airline customers and passengers who are impacted now," Faury posted on LinkedIn.

Friday's alert followed an unintended loss of altitude on an October 30 JetBlue flight from Cancun, Mexico, to Newark, New Jersey, which injured 10 passengers, according to France's BEA accident agency, which is probing the incident.

AIRBUS RECALL LUCKY TIMING FOR SOME AIRLINES

The alert landed at a time of day when many European airlines and Asian airlines are winding down their schedules, leaving time for repairs. In the United States, however, it came during the day ahead of the busy Thanksgiving holiday travel weekend.

U.S. carrier JetBlue said it cancelled about 70 flights that were scheduled for Sunday, with more cancellations possible. JetBlue expects to finish software updates for 120 planes by Sunday morning, but said fixes for about 30 aircraft would still be "in progress" at that point.

About 140 jets in the company's fleet of A320, A321 and A220 aircraft did not need the fix, the company said.

American Airlines, the world's largest A320 operator, said 209 of its 480 jets needed the fix, below initial estimates, most of which it expected to complete by Saturday. United Airlines told Reuters on Saturday that all its aircraft had been updated.

AirAsia, one of the world's largest A320 customers, said it aimed to complete fixes in 48 hours. India's aviation regulator said on Saturday that carriers IndiGo INGL.NS and Air India were expected to complete the process on Saturday. ANA Holdings 9202.T cancelled 95 flights on Saturday, affecting 13,500 travellers.

Taiwan's low-cost airline Tigerair said eight flights would be delayed on Sunday due to the software issue.

Airlines must revert to a previous version of software in a computer that helps determine the nose angle of the affected jets and in some cases must also change the hardware itself, mainly on older planes in service. The fix must be completed before the planes can fly again with passengers, a process needing two to three hours per jet.

Globally, there are about 11,300 of the single-aisle jets in service, including 6,440 of the core A320 model. Those include some of the largest and busiest low-cost carriers.

Tracker data from Cirium and FlightAware showed most global airports operating with good-to-moderate levels of delays.

By Saturday, Airbus was telling airlines that repairs to some of the A320 jets affected may be less burdensome than first thought, industry sources said, with fewer than the original estimate of 1,000 needing the time-consuming hardware changes.

There were also unresolved questions about the impact of solar flare radiation blamed for the JetBlue incident, which is being treated by French investigators as an "incident," the lowest of three categories of potential safety emergency.

"Any operational challenges that come at short notice and affecting a large part of your operation is tough to deal with," said UK-based aviation consultant John Strickland.

(Reuters)

title: Global aviation fuel market trends, segmentation & forecast 2034 - Market Research Intellect
description:
aviation fuel market Overview As per recent data, the aviation fuel market stood at 220 in 2024 and is projected to attain 350 by 2033, with a steady CAGR of 5.3 from 2026-2033.
The Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034 reflects expanding global and regional growth patterns supported by increased flight frequencies, improved refinery output, and wider adoption of sustainable aviation fuel pathways.
Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034 Dynamics The Global Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034 Size represents a critical component of the energy and transportation ecosystem, powering commercial, military, and private aviation worldwide.
Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034 Restraints: Despite strong momentum, the market faces significant Market Challenges.
Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034 Opportunities Emerging Market Opportunities lie in Asia-Pacific, Latin America, and the Middle East, where rising passenger traffic and government-backed sustainability programs are reshaping aviation fuel demand.
text:
aviation fuel market Overview

As per recent data, the aviation fuel market stood at 220 in 2024 and is projected to attain 350 by 2033, with a steady CAGR of 5.3 from 2026-2033.

The Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034 continues to evolve as global air-traffic rebounds and airlines intensify fleet modernization efforts, but one of the strongest real-world drivers shaping industry growth comes from the recent surge in global jet fuel consumption reported by the International Energy Agency, which highlighted substantial increases driven by long-haul travel recovery and cargo aviation demand. This trend directly supports higher refinery output and accelerates investment into cleaner, more efficient fuel technologies. As government authorities strengthen decarbonization mandates and aviation regulators promote sustainable fuel adoption, the aviation sector experiences renewed commercial momentum, particularly across North America which remains the most performance-driven region due to rising passenger numbers, established refinery networks, and growing commitments to sustainable aviation fuel integration.

Aviation fuel plays a pivotal role in enabling commercial airlines, defense fleets, cargo operators, and private aviation companies to operate at scale across global air corridors. It ensures optimal engine efficiency, safe combustion, and stable performance under diverse atmospheric conditions. As the industry expands, aviation fuel development increasingly revolves around refining quality, improving sulfur standards, reducing carbon emissions, and enhancing energy density. Over the past decade, the aviation ecosystem has integrated next-generation biofuel production techniques, advanced blending systems, and airport-based storage innovations, all supporting a more resilient and responsive aviation supply chain. Aviation fuel also benefits from digitalized fuel-management platforms that enhance traceability, reduce logistical inefficiencies, and support real-time consumption monitoring. With global air travel demand showing structural improvement, aviation fuel continues to gain strategic significance as a core operational enabler.

The Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034 reflects expanding global and regional growth patterns supported by increased flight frequencies, improved refinery output, and wider adoption of sustainable aviation fuel pathways. A key driver strengthening industry momentum is the rapid inclusion of bio-based fuel alternatives in commercial fleets as airlines seek lower-emission solutions aligned with national energy policies. The market benefits from rising opportunities in Asia Pacific and the Middle East where next-generation airport infrastructure and cargo expansion stimulate higher aviation fuel requirements. Challenges persist around supply-chain volatility, pricing fluctuations, and infrastructure limitations for large-scale sustainable fuel adoption. However, emerging technologies such as synthetic fuel production, AI-enabled fuel distribution analytics, and advanced refinery catalysts contribute positively to operational efficiency. Supporting industries like the energy logistics market and the renewable fuels market also influence long-term growth as integrated supply strategies become more critical for airlines and fuel suppliers.

Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034 Key Takeaways

Regional Contribution to Market in 2025 (60-80 words):In 2025, North America is expected to lead the aviation fuel market with around 33% share, supported by strong commercial traffic and high jet fuel consumption by major airlines. Asia Pacific follows closely at about 31%, driven by rapid airport expansion and increasing fleets across China and India, making it the fastest-growing region. Europe accounts for nearly 24%, while Latin America and the Middle East & Africa contribute around 7% and 5% respectively, reflecting steady but moderate demand growth.

Market Breakdown by Type in 2025 (60-80 words):Jet A is projected to hold around 45% of the aviation fuel mix in 2025, driven by its extensive use in commercial fleets. Jet A-1 accounts for roughly 37% due to its all-climate suitability. Sustainable Aviation Fuel rises to nearly 13% as airlines accelerate decarbonization commitments, making it the fastest-growing type. Aviation Gasoline holds close to 5%, primarily serving training aircraft and small aviation operators, with growth limited by operational scale.

Largest Sub-segment by Type in 2025 (60-80 words):Jet A remains the largest sub-segment in 2025, maintaining its leadership due to widespread adoption by commercial and cargo aircraft. While Jet A-1 continues to narrow the gap as global fleets standardize on temperature-resilient fuels, the shift remains gradual and does not overturn Jet A dominance. Sustainable Aviation Fuel grows rapidly but remains significantly smaller, serving more as a transition fuel as airlines scale up long-term emission reduction strategies.

Key Applications - Market Share in 2025 (60-80 words):Commercial aviation leads in 2025 with an estimated 63% share due to expanding passenger volumes and broader route networks. Cargo aviation follows with nearly 17% as global e-commerce accelerates aircraft utilization. Military aviation accounts for about 16% with operational consistency, while general aviation represents roughly 4%. Growth in commercial and cargo applications is supported by increased long-haul operations, wider fleet modernization, and rising consumption across both passenger and logistics sectors.

Fastest Growing Application Segment:Commercial aviation is expected to be the fastest-growing application segment, supported by increasing passenger demand, expansion of low-cost carriers, and continuous investments in airport capacity. Technological upgrades in next-generation aircraft further boost utilization rates, while rising tourism, business travel, and regional connectivity drive sustained increases in fuel consumption across developing and mature markets.

Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034 Dynamics

The Global Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034 Size represents a critical component of the energy and transportation ecosystem, powering commercial, military, and private aviation worldwide. As air travel continues to expand, aviation fuel remains indispensable for economic growth and global connectivity. According to the World Bank, aviation contributes significantly to international trade and tourism, reinforcing its industrial significance. This Industry Overview highlights the role of aviation fuel in enabling technological modernization, supporting freight logistics, and sustaining global passenger mobility. With rising sustainability mandates and digital transformation, the sector is positioned for a robust Growth Forecast across diverse regions and applications

Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034 Drivers:

Key Industry Trends driving demand growth include sustainability, innovation, and regulatory alignment. The uptake of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) is accelerating, with global SAF capacity projected to reach nearly 6 billion gallons by 2030, up from 1.3 billion gallons in 2023. This reflects strong Demand Growth as airlines commit to net-zero targets. Technological advancement is another driver, with automation and AI integration in refining processes improving efficiency and reducing emissions. For example, partnerships between aircraft manufacturers and energy firms are fostering R&D in biofuels and hydrogen-based aviation fuels. Regulatory frameworks, such as the EU’s Aviation Fuel Regulation (2023/2405), are further incentivizing SAF adoption. Additionally, industries like Wireless Network Ecosystem market and Treatment Planning Software market demonstrate how cross-sector innovation strengthens aviation fuel supply chains, ensuring resilience and adaptability in global operations.

Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034 Restraints:

Despite strong momentum, the market faces significant Market Challenges. High Cost Constraints in SAF production remain a barrier, with OECD noting that limited feedstock availability and expensive conversion technologies hinder scalability. Regulatory hurdles also complicate deployment, as varying international standards create Regulatory Barriers for global airlines. The World Economic Forum highlights concerns over geopolitical tensions and tariffs, which further elevate costs and disrupt supply chains. Moreover, dependency on fossil-based raw materials continues to limit rapid adoption of alternatives, despite ongoing R&D investments by major fuel producers. These restraints emphasize the need for coordinated policy frameworks and technological breakthroughs to ensure sustainable growth in the aviation fuel sector.

Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034 Opportunities

Emerging Market Opportunities lie in Asia-Pacific, Latin America, and the Middle East, where rising passenger traffic and government-backed sustainability programs are reshaping aviation fuel demand. The Innovation Outlook is defined by strategic partnerships, such as joint ventures between airlines and biofuel producers, which accelerate SAF commercialization. For instance, Latin America’s adoption of SAF under CORSIA mandates demonstrates Future Growth Potential through regulatory alignment and investment in renewable energy infrastructure. Integration of IoT and automation in refining processes enhances efficiency, while green technologies such as hydrogen fuel and power-to-liquid systems expand the innovation pipeline. Industries like Aerospace & Defense market further reinforce aviation fuel’s strategic relevance, as military aviation increasingly explores SAF adoption to meet sustainability targets.

Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034 Challenges:

The Competitive Landscape is marked by intense rivalry among fuel producers, airlines, and technology providers. High R&D intensity and compliance complexity create Industry Barriers, with sustainability regulations tightening across regions. The World Economic Forum notes that scaling SAF requires cross-industry collaboration, improved refinery efficiency, and government engagement. Margin compression is a growing concern, as airlines face rising costs while balancing consumer expectations for affordable travel. Sustainability pressures, including stricter international standards, demand rapid innovation and adaptation. For example, BCG reports that despite SAF production growth, weak demand signals and lack of long-term off-take agreements hinder progress This underscores the need for coordinated investment and policy frameworks to overcome Sustainability Regulations and ensure competitive resilience.

Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034 Segmentation

By Application

Commercial Aviation - Supported by rising passenger traffic and SAF adoption programs initiated by global airlines for carbon-neutral growth.

Military Aviation - Driven by modernization of air fleets, high-performance fuel demand, and strategic fuel security investments.

General Aviation - Benefiting from increased private aircraft operations and improved fuel distribution networks at regional airports.

Cargo & Logistics Aviation - Growing due to e-commerce expansion and greater need for high-efficiency jet fuel for long-haul operations.

Helicopter Aviation - Boosted by offshore exploration, medical emergency transport, and defense operations requiring premium-grade aviation fuel.

By Product

Jet A Fuel - Dominates global usage thanks to its efficiency, safety profile, and compatibility with commercial aircraft fleets.

Jet A-1 Fuel - Preferred by international airlines due to its superior freezing point and suitability for long-haul flights.

JP-5 Fuel - Widely used for naval and carrier-based aircraft because of its high flash point and operational safety in maritime conditions.

JP-8 Fuel - A key fuel for military forces worldwide owing to its universal battlefield utility and standardized NATO adoption.

Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) - Expected to witness the fastest growth as airlines, governments, and refiners accelerate production to meet global net-zero aviation commitments.

By Key Players

Recent Developments In Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034

Recent activity in the aviation fuel sector has been shaped strongly by new long-term supply agreements and strategic fuel-trade partnerships. One of the most significant developments came when Unipec, the trading arm of Sinopec, finalized a multi-year agreement to supply Lufthansa with around 60,000 metric tons of jet fuel per year, reinforcing stable jet-fuel availability across key airports in Germany and Belgium. This deal also reflects an expansion of Unipec’s broader aviation-fuel footprint, as the company has been supplying millions of tons of jet fuel annually across Europe and North Africa. At the same time, major airlines such as KLM have deepened cooperation with fuel traders to secure consistent access to both conventional jet fuel and sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), highlighting the continued need for diversified supply channels.

Investments in sustainable aviation fuel production have accelerated sharply, with multiple energy companies and aircraft manufacturers backing large-scale commercial SAF projects. One of the largest commitments came from Ecopetrol, Colombia’s national oil company, which approved US $500-700 million for constructing a new SAF production plant integrated into its Barrancabermeja refinery. The plant is being designed to produce roughly 6,000 barrels per day once operational — a milestone that would position Colombia as a key regional supplier. Parallel to this, Airbus expanded its role beyond aircraft manufacturing by co-founding a dedicated financing alliance for SAF projects and investing directly in LanzaJet to scale its Alcohol-to-Jet production pathway. These investments illustrate how the aviation ecosystem is moving from pilot projects to industrial-scale SAF capacity backed by major energy and aerospace stakeholders.

Regulatory and operational developments have also transformed the aviation fuel landscape across major regions. In the European Union, the ReFuelEU Aviation regulation entered key implementation phases in 2025, with mandated SAF blending requirements beginning at 2% for all EU airports and preparing for higher obligations in the coming years. This regulatory pressure has already driven airports and fuel suppliers to adjust logistics, certification, and blending infrastructure. Meanwhile, in India, Boeing partnered with Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Limited to advance a domestic SAF ecosystem, working on certification pathways, feedstock optimization, and nationwide supply-chain planning. Boeing additionally highlighted India’s potential to produce up to 8-10 million metric tons of SAF annually due to its agricultural-residue base, indicating that new producer nations are emerging beyond the traditional jet-fuel hubs. Collectively, these developments show a global shift in how aviation fuel is produced, regulated, and supplied — with SAF integration now embedded in national strategies, airline procurement models, and manufacturer-led innovation programs.

Global Aviation Fuel Market Trends, Segmentation & Forecast 2034: Research Methodology

The research methodology includes both primary and secondary research, as well as expert panel reviews. Secondary research utilises press releases, company annual reports, research papers related to the industry, industry periodicals, trade journals, government websites, and associations to collect precise data on business expansion opportunities. Primary research entails conducting telephone interviews, sending questionnaires via email, and, in some instances, engaging in face-to-face interactions with a variety of industry experts in various geographic locations. Typically, primary interviews are ongoing to obtain current market insights and validate the existing data analysis. The primary interviews provide information on crucial factors such as market trends, market size, the competitive landscape, growth trends, and future prospects. These factors contribute to the validation and reinforcement of secondary research findings and to the growth of the analysis team’s market knowledge.

Shares of Par Pacific Holdings have been surging on strong momentum, up 31.8% over the last three months and reporting an impressive year-to-date share price return of 173.5%. Following recent deal activity and positive quarterly results, investors seem to be reassessing the company's long-term growth potential. This has been reflected in a 161.9% total return over the past year.

If Par Pacific’s pace has you rethinking where to spot the next breakout, it’s a great moment to broaden your search and discover

Most Popular Narrative: 3.6% Undervalued

Par Pacific Holdings’ widely tracked fair value estimate is $47.38, just above the last close of $45.65. This presents a close contest between market optimism and fundamentals. The stage is set for deeper analysis as investors weigh these valuations against the company's performance and projections.

The strategic partnership with Mitsubishi and ENEOS, along with the upcoming SAF (Sustainable Aviation Fuel) project launch, positions Par Pacific for growth in renewable fuels. Another View: Looking Through the Market’s Lens

Stepping away from fair value models, let’s consider where Par Pacific stands versus its peers by looking at the price-to-earnings ratio. Par Pacific trades at 9.7x, which is lower than the industry average of 13.4x and the peer average of 23.3x, but slightly higher than its own fair ratio estimate of 8.4x. This may indicate current optimism or additional valuation risk. Could the market be overlooking something, or is this a value trap in disguise?

title: Com a chegada de Filipinas, Guatemala e Nicarágua, Brasil abre 496 mercados desde 2023
description:
O governo brasileiro anunciou a conclusão de negociações sanitárias e fitossanitárias com as Filipinas, a Guatemala e a Nicarágua, o que permitirá a ampliação das exportações de diversos produtos agropecuários para esses três mercados.
Nas Filipinas, as autoridades sanitárias aprovaram a importação de gordura bovina brasileira, insumo utilizado pela indústria de alimentos e pela cadeia de biocombustíveis.
Com cerca de 115 milhões de habitantes, as Filipinas figuram entre os maiores mercados consumidores do Sudeste Asiático e importaram quase US$ 1,5 bilhão em produtos agropecuários do Brasil entre janeiro e outubro de 2025.
Entre janeiro e outubro de 2025, a Nicarágua importou aproximadamente US$ 55 milhões em produtos agropecuários do Brasil.
Com os novos anúncios, o agronegócio brasileiro alcança 496 aberturas de mercado desde o início de 2023, reforçando a estratégia de diversificação de destinos e de inclusão de produtos de maior valor agregado no comércio internacional.
text:
O governo brasileiro anunciou a conclusão de negociações sanitárias e fitossanitárias com as Filipinas, a Guatemala e a Nicarágua, o que permitirá a ampliação das exportações de diversos produtos agropecuários para esses três mercados. As novas autorizações somam-se ao esforço de diversificação do agronegócio nacional e resultam do trabalho conjunto entre o Ministério da Agricultura e Pecuária (Mapa) e o Ministério das Relações Exteriores (MRE).

Nas Filipinas, as autoridades sanitárias aprovaram a importação de gordura bovina brasileira, insumo utilizado pela indústria de alimentos e pela cadeia de biocombustíveis. O produto é essencial para a produção de diesel verde e de “Sustainable Aviation Fuel” (SAF), contribuindo para a expansão de fontes de energia de baixo carbono. Com cerca de 115 milhões de habitantes, as Filipinas figuram entre os maiores mercados consumidores do Sudeste Asiático e importaram quase US$ 1,5 bilhão em produtos agropecuários do Brasil entre janeiro e outubro de 2025.

Na Guatemala, o Brasil obteve autorização fitossanitária para exportar arroz beneficiado (sem casca). O país centro-americano, com população de cerca de 18 milhões de pessoas, importou mais de US$ 192 milhões em produtos do agronegócio brasileiro no mesmo período de 2025, com os cereais entre os principais itens adquiridos.

A Nicarágua também ampliou o acesso de produtos brasileiros ao aprovar a importação de sementes de milheto, crotalária e nabo, insumos estratégicos para a agricultura tropical. Essas sementes contribuem para o aumento da produtividade, a melhoria do solo e a redução da dependência de fertilizantes minerais. Entre janeiro e outubro de 2025, a Nicarágua importou aproximadamente US$ 55 milhões em produtos agropecuários do Brasil.

Com os novos anúncios, o agronegócio brasileiro alcança 496 aberturas de mercado desde o início de 2023, reforçando a estratégia de diversificação de destinos e de inclusão de produtos de maior valor agregado no comércio internacional.

Fonte: Ministério das Relações Exteriores do Brasil.

title: Verissimo, Vitagliano: "Ho vissuto giorni da incubo. Mia figlia la cosa più importante"
description:
(Adnkronos) – "Sto meglio, ho ripreso 20 chili, mi hanno tolto il cortisone e sono felice di guardarmi ora allo specchio".
Con queste parole Costantino Vitagliano ospite oggi a Verissimo ha parlato delle sue condizioni di salute e degli ultimi due anni della sua vita segnati da una malattia autoimmune, che provoca problemi ai vasi sanguigni.
"Ho vissuto dei giorni da incubo.
Costantino è papà di Ayla, nata nel 2015: "Sono davvero orgoglioso di mia figlia.
Prima ero troppo preso da me e da quello che era il mio lavoro, non pensando che oggi la cosa più importante è questa: fare il papà", ha detto a Verissimo.
text:
(Adnkronos) –

"Sto meglio, ho ripreso 20 chili, mi hanno tolto il cortisone e sono felice di guardarmi ora allo specchio". Con queste parole Costantino Vitagliano ospite oggi a Verissimo ha parlato delle sue condizioni di salute e degli ultimi due anni della sua vita segnati da una malattia autoimmune, che provoca problemi ai vasi sanguigni. "Ho vissuto dei giorni da incubo. Avevo delle ansie pazzesche, pensavo che fosse finito un ciclo di vita. Pensavo solo in negativo, non avevo le forze di fare nulla. Sono stato 40 giorni a pensare che non ce l'avrei fatta, le persone intorno mi hanno dato tanta energia", ha detto Vitagliano ospite nel salotto di Silvia Toffanin, che oggi, grazie alle cure, non rischia più la vita. Costantino è papà di Ayla, nata nel 2015: "Sono davvero orgoglioso di mia figlia. Prima ero troppo preso da me e da quello che era il mio lavoro, non pensando che oggi la cosa più importante è questa: fare il papà", ha detto a Verissimo. Vitagliano temeva di non essere in grado di fare il padre: "Elisa (Mariani, la mamma di Ayla, ndr) mi ha dato la cosa più bella della mia vita e io all'inizio non la capivo, non mi sentivo pronto, avevo paura, pensavo di non essere all'altezza, oggi le dico grazie per avermi fatto questo dono".

—spettacoliwebinfo@adnkronos.com (Web Info)

title: Do Sustainable Aviation Fuel Mandates Catalyze Decarbonization? Evidence from Europe's ...
description:
Abstract Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) mandates are a critical policy for decarbonizing aviation, yet their real-world effectiveness remains empirically unverified.
This study provides one of the first quasi-experimental comparative evaluations of pioneering mandates in Norway, Sweden, and France (2018–2023).
Our results reveal highly heterogeneous impacts: France achieved a remarkable 22.1% reduction in carbon efficiency (emissions per RPK) post-mandate, Sweden showed moderate improvements, while pioneer Norway exhibited no measurable gains.
These findings provide rare empirical validation that mandates can succeed, functioning as institutional catalysts that accelerate strategic efficiency investments beyond mere fuel compliance.
This research underscores that policy effectiveness is highly contingent on national context and design, offering crucial insights for global aviation's green transformation.
text:
Abstract

Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) mandates are a critical policy for decarbonizing aviation, yet their real-world effectiveness remains empirically unverified. This study provides one of the first quasi-experimental comparative evaluations of pioneering mandates in Norway, Sweden, and France (2018–2023). We employ a novel analytical framework, integrating survival analysis with high-resolution flight data, to overcome severe methodological constraints, including small sample size and the confounding COVID-19 shock. Our results reveal highly heterogeneous impacts: France achieved a remarkable 22.1% reduction in carbon efficiency (emissions per RPK) post-mandate, Sweden showed moderate improvements, while pioneer Norway exhibited no measurable gains. These findings provide rare empirical validation that mandates can succeed, functioning as institutional catalysts that accelerate strategic efficiency investments beyond mere fuel compliance. This research underscores that policy effectiveness is highly contingent on national context and design, offering crucial insights for global aviation's green transformation.
